definitions: declare the punishment to be imposed on someone found guilty of a crime in a court of law
form or express a complete thought using a grammatical structure containing a subject and predicate
examples: The judge will sentence the defendant tomorrow morning
The court sentenced him to five years in prison
Students learn to sentence their ideas clearly and correctly
The writer carefully sentences each thought in the paragraph

definitions: cause to divide into two or more parts or sections by putting something between them
move or cause to move apart from each other creating distance or space
stop living together as a married couple or end a romantic relationship
recognize or identify the differences between things making them distinct
examples: Please separate the whites from the colors before washing
The wall separates the two properties completely
The crowd separated to let the ambulance through
They separated the fighting children immediately
The couple decided to separate after ten years together
They separated but remained friends for the children
It's hard to separate fact from fiction in his stories
We need to separate personal feelings from professional duties

definitions: arrange things in a particular order following a logical or chronological pattern
determine the exact order of nucleotides in DNA or amino acids in proteins
examples: The teacher asked students to sequence the historical events correctly
We need to sequence these tasks by priority level
The laboratory will sequence the virus genome this week
Scientists sequenced the patient's DNA to identify mutations

definitions: isolate a jury during a trial to prevent outside influence on their deliberations
chemically bind or separate a substance making it unavailable for reactions
keep someone away from other people in an isolated or secluded place
examples: The judge decided to sequester the jury for the high-profile case
They will sequester the jury throughout the entire trial
The treatment sequesters iron in the blood preventing toxicity
These plants sequester carbon dioxide from the atmosphere
The author sequestered himself in a cabin to finish the novel
They sequestered the witness in a safe house

definitions: sing or play music to someone as a romantic gesture typically outside their window
perform a piece of evening music especially one in several movements for a small orchestra
examples: He serenaded her beneath her bedroom window with his guitar
The mariachi band serenaded the couple at their anniversary dinner
The orchestra will serenade the guests with Mozart this evening
The musicians serenaded the crowd with classical pieces

definitions: create a jagged edge with sharp projections resembling the teeth of a saw
examples: The machine serrates the metal edges for better grip
They serrate the knife blade during the manufacturing process

definitions: present food or drink to someone or act as a waiter or waitress
work for a person or organization performing duties or providing help
spend a period of time in a particular position job or military service
act in a particular capacity or fulfill a specific function or purpose
hit the ball to start play in tennis volleyball or similar games
deliver a legal document such as a summons or writ to someone
examples: The waiter served dinner at exactly seven o'clock
She serves breakfast to her family every morning
He has served the company loyally for twenty years
The secretary serves three different executives
She served in the army for four years
He served two terms as mayor of the city
This table serves as both desk and dining surface
The old barn now serves as an art studio
She served three aces in the final game
It's your turn to serve the volleyball
The lawyer served divorce papers yesterday afternoon
They served him with a court summons

definitions: perform routine maintenance or repair work on a vehicle or machine to keep it operating
pay the interest on a debt but not reduce the principal amount owed
provide sexual services professionally or mate with an animal for breeding
examples: The mechanic will service your car tomorrow morning
We service all heating systems twice each year
The company can barely service its massive debt
They struggle to service the loan each month
The bull services cows throughout the breeding season
The stallion serviced twenty mares last year

definitions: put place or stand something in a specified position or location
become solid firm or hard changing from a liquid or soft state
establish or decide upon rules standards prices or other conditions
adjust a device clock or control to a particular position or level
appear to move toward and below the horizon as the sun or moon
arrange the scenery properties or action for a play film or story
examples: Set the vase carefully on the table
She set the book down beside her bed
The concrete will set within twenty-four hours
Leave the jelly to set in the refrigerator
The committee will set new guidelines next month
They set the price at fifty dollars
Please set your watch to the correct time
Set the oven temperature to three hundred degrees
The sun sets earlier in winter months
We watched the moon set over the ocean
They set the scene in Victorian London
The crew sets the stage for tonight's performance

definitions: resolve or reach an agreement about an argument or problem through discussion
establish a permanent residence in a place or colonize a new area
sink slowly downward under weight or come to rest at the bottom
become calm quiet or still after a period of activity or excitement
pay a debt or bill in full completing the financial obligation
examples: The lawyers settled the case out of court yesterday
They finally settled their differences after long negotiations
European immigrants settled the midwest in the nineteenth century
The family settled in California after the war
The dust settled slowly after the construction ended
The foundation has settled two inches this year
The baby finally settled after hours of crying
Wait for the crowd to settle before speaking
He settled all his debts before leaving town
I'll settle the bill at the restaurant

definitions: cut through something completely using a sharp tool or great force to separate parts
end a relationship connection or association completely and usually permanently
examples: The accident severed his spinal cord completely
The surgeon had to sever the damaged nerve
The company severed all ties with the supplier
She severed contact with her toxic family members

definitions: join attach or repair something by making stitches with a needle and thread
make clothes or other items by joining pieces of fabric with stitches
examples: She learned to sew buttons when she was seven
Can you sew this tear in my jacket?
My grandmother sews beautiful quilts every winter
He sews costumes for the local theater group

definitions: determine the biological sex of an animal or plant through examination
engage in sexual activity or have sexual intercourse with someone
examples: The veterinarian will sex the chicks tomorrow morning
It's difficult to sex young kittens accurately
They sexed in the hotel room after dinner
The teenagers were caught sexing in the car

definitions: live together as unmarried partners in an informal or temporary arrangement usually followed by up
examples: They decided to shack up after dating for six months
He's been shacking with his girlfriend downtown

definitions: put shackles or chains on someone's wrists or ankles to prevent movement
restrict or limit someone's freedom actions or development in a metaphorical sense
examples: The guards shackled the prisoner before transport
They shackled his ankles and wrists with heavy chains
Debt shackles many families preventing them from prosperity
Old traditions shackle progress in some communities

definitions: screen from direct light especially sunlight by interposing something between
darken or color an illustration or diagram with parallel lines or a block of color
change or vary slightly or by degrees into something else
examples: The large oak tree shades our patio perfectly
She shaded her eyes with her hand
The artist carefully shaded the portrait with charcoal
Students learn to shade drawings in art class
The blue shades into green at the horizon
Her opinion shades toward the conservative side

definitions: follow and observe someone closely and secretly especially as part of surveillance
cast a shadow over something blocking light or creating darkness
examples: The detective shadowed the suspect for three days
Security agents shadow the diplomat everywhere she goes
Dark clouds shadowed the valley all afternoon
The tall building shadows the park completely

definitions: treat someone harshly or unfairly especially by cheating or taking advantage of them
examples: The company really shafted its workers with that contract
He got shafted in the business deal last year

definitions: engage in sexual intercourse especially in a casual encounter
practice catching fly balls in baseball during warm-up or practice
dance a vigorous dance popular in the 1930s with hopping steps
examples: They shagged in the back of his van
He's been shagging his neighbor for months
The outfielders shagged flies during batting practice
Players shag balls before every game
They shagged to swing music all night long
Couples were shagging on the dance floor

definitions: move or cause to move with short quick movements from side to side or up and down
tremble or cause to tremble as a result of physical or emotional disturbance
upset the composure or confidence of someone making them feel disturbed or shocked
mix ingredients by putting them in a container and moving it rapidly
examples: Shake the bottle well before opening it
The earthquake shook buildings for thirty seconds
His hands shake when he's nervous
Fear shook her entire body
The accident really shook him up badly
News of the scandal shook the entire community
Shake the cocktail with ice for ten seconds
She shakes protein powder into her smoothie

definitions: become less deep gradually as water level drops or bottom rises
examples: The river shallows considerably during summer months
The channel has shallowed over the years from sedimentation

definitions: pretend to be or have something falsely in order to deceive others
examples: She shammed illness to avoid the meeting
He's been shamming expertise he doesn't actually possess

definitions: make someone feel ashamed embarrassed or inadequate often by public criticism
bring shame or dishonor to someone or something through one's actions
examples: Don't shame people for their mistakes in public
Her parents shamed her into apologizing
His behavior shamed the entire family
The scandal shamed the institution's reputation

definitions: wash hair carpet or upholstery with shampoo to clean and remove dirt
examples: She shampoos her hair every other day
The cleaner will shampoo all the carpets tomorrow

definitions: force or trick someone into doing something especially joining a ship's crew
drug or knock out someone and take them aboard a ship to serve as crew
examples: They shanghaied him into organizing the entire event
Sailors were often shanghaied in port cities
Pirates would shanghai drunk men from taverns
He was shanghaied onto a merchant vessel

definitions: strike a golf ball with the heel of the club causing it to go sharply right
examples: He shanked his approach shot into the water
Don't shank the ball on this crucial hole

definitions: give a particular form or shape to something by molding cutting or arranging
have a significant influence on the development or nature of something
improve physical fitness or condition through exercise often with up
examples: The potter shapes clay on the wheel
She shaped the dough into small rolls
Early experiences shape our adult personality
These events shaped the course of history
He's shaping up for the marathon
You need to shape up or ship out

definitions: give a portion of something to others or divide something between people
tell someone about something especially personal information thoughts or feelings
have or use something jointly with another person or group
examples: Please share your candy with your sister
They shared the profits equally among partners
She shared her concerns with the counselor
He rarely shares his feelings with anyone
We share an office on the third floor
The siblings share similar interests in music

definitions: obtain something through cheating swindling or using unethical business practices
examples: He sharked money from unsuspecting tourists
They shark people at that shady casino

definitions: make or become sharp or sharper by grinding honing or wearing to an edge
improve or cause to improve in clarity focus or mental alertness
make or become more intense acute or clearly defined
examples: Please sharpen all the kitchen knives today
The blade sharpens easily with this stone
Chess helps sharpen your strategic thinking skills
Coffee sharpens my mind in the morning
Competition sharpened their rivalry even more
The contrast sharpens between light and dark

definitions: break suddenly and violently into many small pieces typically with a loud noise
destroy someone emotionally or psychologically causing severe distress or trauma
examples: The ball shattered the window into tiny fragments
The glass shattered when it hit the floor
The diagnosis shattered her completely
His betrayal shattered her trust forever

definitions: remove hair from the face or body using a razor or similar tool
reduce something by a small amount especially time or cost
pass very close to something barely avoiding contact
examples: He shaves every morning before work
She decided to shave her legs for summer
The new route shaves ten minutes off the commute
They shaved costs by reducing staff
The car shaved the curb while parking
The bullet shaved past his ear

definitions: cut the wool off a sheep or cut something with shears or a similar tool
break or cause to break from structural stress typically along a plane
examples: Farmers shear sheep every spring for wool
He sheared the hedge into a perfect square
The bolt sheared under excessive pressure
Strong winds can shear tree branches easily

definitions: lose hair leaves or skin naturally as part of growth or seasonal change
get rid of something unwanted or unnecessary deliberately
cast or spread light over an area or in a particular direction
allow liquid especially tears or blood to flow or fall
examples: Snakes shed their skin several times yearly
The tree sheds its leaves in autumn
She's trying to shed ten pounds before summer
The company shed workers during the recession
The lamp sheds soft light across the room
This evidence sheds new light on the case
He shed tears at his daughter's wedding
The wounded soldier shed blood on the battlefield

definitions: change direction suddenly especially to avoid collision typically used of ships or vehicles
examples: The ship sheered away from the rocks
The driver sheered left to avoid the deer

definitions: cover or wrap something with a large flat piece of material
flow or fall in a broad flat mass like a sheet of water
examples: They sheeted the furniture before painting
Workers sheeted the building during construction
Rain was sheeting down the windows
Water sheeted across the parking lot

definitions: remove the shell or outer covering from nuts eggs or shellfish
bombard with artillery shells or other explosive projectiles
examples: She shells peas for dinner every Sunday
It takes time to shell all these pistachios
Enemy forces shelled the city all night
The artillery shelled their positions for hours

definitions: apply shellac varnish to wood or other surfaces for protection and shine
defeat someone thoroughly and decisively in a competition or conflict
examples: He shellacked the antique table three times
The carpenter shellacs all custom furniture pieces
Our team got shellacked in yesterday's game
The champion shellacked every opponent this season

definitions: provide a place of protection or safety from weather danger or hardship
take cover or find protection from bad weather or danger
examples: The charity shelters homeless families every winter
Trees shelter the house from strong winds
We sheltered in a cave during the storm
Birds shelter under the eaves when it rains

definitions: guide or direct a group of people in a protective and careful manner
tend watch over and guide sheep as an occupation
examples: The teacher shepherded the children through the museum
She shepherded the project to successful completion
He shepherds his flock in mountain pastures
The dog helps shepherd sheep into the pen

definitions: protect someone or something from danger harm or unpleasant experience
examples: Parents try to shield children from violence
The umbrella shielded her from the rain

definitions: move or cause to move from one position place or direction to another
change gear in a vehicle to control speed or power
transfer responsibility blame or emphasis from one thing to another
examples: She shifted her weight to the other foot
The crowd shifted toward the stage
He shifted into third gear on the highway
Learn to shift gears smoothly while driving
Don't shift blame onto your colleagues
The focus shifted to economic issues

definitions: shine with a soft tremulous light that seems to move slightly
examples: The lake shimmered in the moonlight
Her dress shimmered as she walked

definitions: dance or move with a shaking wiggling motion of the body especially the hips
shake or vibrate abnormally especially of a vehicle wheel or mechanical part
examples: She shimmied across the dance floor
The dancer shimmied to the jazz music
The front wheel shimmies at high speed
The washing machine shimmies during spin cycle

definitions: climb quickly up or down something by gripping with arms and legs
examples: The boy shinned up the tree effortlessly
She shinned down the drainpipe to escape

definitions: give out bright light or be bright with reflected light
polish something until it gleams or make something smooth and bright
be very good at something or perform excellently in an activity
examples: The sun shines brightly this morning
Her eyes shined with excitement
He shines his shoes every Sunday morning
She shined the silver until it gleamed
She really shines in mathematics class
This is where his talent shines

definitions: cover a roof or wall with overlapping rows of flat rectangular tiles
examples: They will shingle the roof next week
The contractor shingled three houses this month

definitions: send goods or cargo to a destination especially by mail or commercial transport
transport goods or passengers by ship across water
serve as a sailor on a ship or embark on a voyage
examples: We ship orders within twenty-four hours
The company ships products worldwide
They ship cargo across the Atlantic monthly
The goods were shipped from China
He shipped out with the navy last year
Young men shipped as deckhands for adventure

definitions: cause the destruction of a ship by sinking or breaking up at sea
examples: The storm shipwrecked three vessels last night
Pirates shipwrecked merchant ships along this coast

definitions: avoid or neglect a duty or responsibility through laziness or cowardice
examples: Don't shirk your responsibilities at work
He shirks his duties whenever possible
